Executive Summary

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Signal Hill Petroleum has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment

is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and

consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Gas Processing System.

Signal Hill Petroleum's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of

regulated substance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Propane, butane, pentane methane, ethane, isobutane, hexane and isopentane are the regulated

substances at Signal Hill Petroleum. These regulated substances are stored as a flammable mixture

in storage bullets near the facility fence line. The maximum intended inventory for the facility is

outlined in the Process Chemicals section of the attached RMPeSubmit pages. The Process Safety

Information chapter of the compliance workbook also contains the inventory calculations for the

system.



Risk Considerations

Although the storage and processing of flammables has inherent potential risks, and worst-case

release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Signal Hill Petroleum has recognized these

potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.

In addition to the safety practices of the company and facility personnel to make this worst-case

event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that

make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be

expected during such an event. In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that

over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to

minimize the potential risks associated with a flammable release:

-There are process valves to permit isolation of any leaks in place.

-The syste

m undergoes scheduled maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

-Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by facility personnel, as necessary.

-A well designed relief system



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

As part of the implementation of CalARP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were

documented and implemented by Signal Hill Petroleum to manage process safety issues associated

with the processing of flammables. Prevention Program 3 elements are listed below:

2760.1 Process Safety Information (PSI)

2760.2 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

2760.3 Operating Procedures (OP)

2760.4 Training (TRN)

2760.5 Mechanical Integrity (MI)

2760.6 Management of Change (MOC)

2760.7 Pre-Startup Review (PSSR)

2760.8 Compliance Audits (CA)

2760.9 Incident Investigation (II)

2760.10 Employee Participation (EP)

2760.11 Hot Work Permit (HWP)

2760.12 Contractors (CON)

Article 7 Emergency Planning & Response (EP&R)



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No reportable accidents have occurred within the last 5 years.



EXTERNAL EVENTS ASSESSMENT

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.7(q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of flammables were addressed by the 2019 Process Hazard Analysis for the system. Specifically, the external events requirements were met with the following actions:

Description of the types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2.

- During the Process Hazard Analysis, a broad list of external events was considered by the Team. However, the Team only deemed some of these events as being credible, and fully developed those scenarios that present an opportunity for flammables release. The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Signal Hill Petroleum has implemented an Emergency Action Plan and does not assume the role of first responder during an emergency. Signal Hill Petroleum has filed a plan with the Los Angeles County Fire Department and this plan includes:

- Emergency Alarm Procedures

- Evacuation Procedures

- Safety and Health Considerations

- Notification Procedures



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Signal Hill Petroleum is extremely diligent in the handling of flammables. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the PHA Report which can be found behind the PHA Tab in the CalARP Compliance Workbook.
